reviewText: This is a movie that could have taken place at any time; it had little bearing on the holiday.The problem with this movie is the casting; Christine Baranski is way too good.  If we're supposed to believe, and side with, her poor put-upon daughter (Carly Pope), her mother is a monster.  Unfortunately, it's the daughter who's a monster and a total drag, while her mom is the life of any party.  Love watching Baranski in almost anything, but I had to put up with a lot to enjoy her in this venue.  Carly Pope drains every scene she's in.  Bobby Cannavale's part could have been played by anyone and it wouldn't have mattered in the least.  The only thing that holds this movie together is Christine Baranski (and she gets to sing too!).  This was like watching a barely fleshed-out sitcom rerun.Otherwise.....didn't mind watching it once, but it's not something to add to my Christmas collection.

reviewText: This is another movie we bought new this season, and mainly I was curious to see Christine B because the others had actors I didn't recognize.  I think this would be considered a mediocre role for Baranski, who has done many other better roles.  She isn't a bad actor, but when I'm used to seeing her in a comedy this felt uncomfortable watching her play such a desperate character.  The movie has some racier moments (a nightclub & a bar scene) as one reviewer said, so it is not a family movie for young kids.  This would be one you may watch once a year during Christmas, but most people would not watch it numerous times like It's a Wonderful Life.  It's a Lifetime movie--not the best, and not the worst.  For most people, it's worth renting but not worth buying unless you're a huge Lifetime fan.  The ending turns out happy and with closure, so in that sense it's an OK Christmas movie, just not A+++ in my opinion.

reviewText: Even my husband enjoyed this one ~ even though he usually calls my sappy-love stories "B" Movies. I was surprised I actually enjoyed this movie and it was not all the predictable fare I was expecting. A good perspective for a "grown-up" child viewing their parent getting older, and how age is looked upon in the entertainment industry, and battled. I think it was well-acted, directed and written. Lifetime had its usual gay-couple thrown in for a brief moment, as most of their movies do -- for no apparent reason, just their agenda I assume. Otherwise, clean family viewing--language good and no bedroom scenes.

reviewText: This movie was so much more than I expected, it's hard to know where to start.  Christine Baranski is a wonderful actress, have never seen her in anything where she was less than superb--but this movie gave a different perspective on her as someone vulnerable who has made mistakes and is doing her best to rectify them.  Bobby Cannavale is charming and believable as a man drowning in day-to-day dreck (and who can't relate to that in this day and age?) while trying to live his dream and Carly Pope did a good job, although I thought she could have given her character a little more depth.  The storyline is fairly simple, but it all makes for a really feel good experience, and one to be enjoyed over and over again through the years.  Bravo Lifetime!
summary: Waited too long to see this one--GREAT!
